awd_abstract_narration:
Cyber-molecular systems are networks of nanoscale physical devices in which computation controls the behavior and activities of the molecular devices.  In some cyber-molecular systems the programmable controller itself is implemented by DNA gates and algorithms.  Many of the planned future uses of cyber-molecular systems are safety-critical, such as biosensors to detect pollutants in water or disease markers in the body, and drug therapeutics to deliver a customized medicine only to the locations in the body where the disease has been detected.  

The problem is how to design cyber-molecular systems to be safe for use in a dynamic and only partially understood physical environment.  This project addresses this problem by introducing a new model of chemical reaction networks that can be implemented robustly.  The class of computations accepted by the model can be implemented in such a way that they will provably perform correctly even when crucial physical parameters are perturbed by small amounts. The project will leverage this advance to establish an end-to-end safety-aware perspective for creating cyber-molecular systems. The approach entails tightly integrated computational and physical risk analyses; advances in reaction-network-based modeling and verification techniques; and model-driven experimentation and evaluation on prototyped cyber-molecular systems. 

This project has the potential to make future cyber-molecular systems safer. Results also will provide capabilities in risk analysis and automated verification to meet the need for future certification of safety-critical cyber-molecular systems, such as biosensors and drug therapeutics.  More broadly, the new model of biochemical reaction networks will advance understanding of how to analyze very large sets of nanoscale cyber-physical systems that operate in a probabilistic physical environment from a safety perspective. This project will also focus on interdisciplinary training of a diverse student population, and results will be integrated into undergraduate and graduate courses.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to develop new automated modeling and analysis techniques to improve the design of safe cyber-molecular systems.  Cyber-molecular systems are networks of nanoscale physical devices in which computation, implemented in molecular gates and algorithms, controls the behavior and communication among the molecular devices.  

The project aimed to provide developers with techniques to design cyber-molecular systems that will be safe for use in a dynamic and only partially understood physical environment.  To this end, we developed, applied and evaluated new techniques for programming cyber-molecular systems, including in experimentation on prototype nanodevices.

Many planned uses of cyber-molecular systems are safety-critical, such as sensors to detect pollutants in water or disease markers in the body, and drug therapeutics to deliver a customized medicine only to the locations in the body where the disease has been detected.   We investigated an important class of these systems, namely molecular programmed, self-assembling DNA systems, and developed a safety-aware, software engineering inspired design approach to creating them.  

We used this approach to create design models of several essential building blocks for safe systems, including for state logging, failure detection and recovery, and robust automata and digital logic circuits. The final verified models helped determine specific parameters for some laboratory experiments.

Importantly for safety-critical systems, we introduced a new model of reaction networks that can be implemented robustly.   The class of computations accepted by the model can be implemented in such a way that they provably perform correctly despite any small perturbations that might occur, either in their environments, their initial conditions, or in their physical parameters, during operations.

We also discovered a hidden gap in current verification approaches and worked to fix it.  We first showed that even simple molecular systems, modeled as reaction networks, can have sudden behavioral transitions when they reach a high?but realistic--number of devices operating simultaneously.  This unexpected behavior challenges current approaches to verifying behavior via simulation, model checking, or approximation.  We then showed that formal theorem provers can successfully verify some such systems where other verification methods fail.    

We introduced a new programming language that, by representing the design model as a reactive dataflow network, makes reasoning about molecular programs easier.  We also solved an open problem showing the additional capability of reaction networks to control self-assembly.

We developed and deployed new techniques for tool-supported, design-stage safety analysis of cyber-molecular systems.  Beyond safety, this may also reduce the build-and-test cycles needed for future cyber-molecular systems.  More broadly, the new model of reaction networks advances understanding of how to analyze very large sets of nanoscale cyber-physical systems that operate in a probabilistic physical environment from a safety perspective.  The project contributed significantly to the growth of this emerging field by training ten graduate students in interdisciplinary molecular programming research.  Several have already done additional noteworthy work in the field as scientists and professors. We also involved undergraduate students in our research, and we taught a course on nanoscale self-assembly.   Toward building awareness of safe cyber-molecular systems, we gave tutorials, public lectures, and invited talks. Project results have been published in multiple papers, and the algorithms and experimental data are available for future research and education.
